chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: All right.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So I'll begin today's lecture by giving a brief recap

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: of risk stratification.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: We didn't get to finish talking about survival modeling

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: on Thursday, and so I'll go a little bit more into that.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And I'll answer some of the questions

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that arose during our discussions and on Piazza

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: since.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And then the vast majority of today's lecture

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: will be talking about a new topic,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: in particular, physiological time series modeling.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: I'll give two examples of physiological time series

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: modeling, the first one coming from monitoring patients

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: in intensive care units, and the second one

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: asking a very different type of question,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that of diagnosing patient's heart conditions using EKGs.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And both of these correspond to readings

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that you had for today's lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and we'll go into much more depth of those papers today,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and I'll provide much more color around them.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So just to briefly remind you where we were on Thursday,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: we talked about how one could form-wise risk stratification

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: instead of as a classification problem of what would happen,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: let's say, in some predefined time period,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: rather thinking about risk stratification

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: as a regression question or regression task.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Given what you know about a patient at time 0,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: predicting time to event.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So for example, here, the events might be death, divorce,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: college graduation.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: At patient 1, that event happened at time step 9.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Patient 2, that event happened at time step 12.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And for patient 4, we don't know when that event happened

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: because it was censored.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: In particular, after time step 7,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: we no longer get a view of any of the patient's data,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and so we don't know when that red dot would be,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: sometime in the future or never.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So this is what we mean by right-censored data, which

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is precisely what survival modeling is aiming to solve.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Are there questions about this setup first?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: AUDIENCE MEMBER 2 You flipped the X and the O.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Yeah, I realized that.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: I flipped the X and the O in today's presentation,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: but that's not relevant.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So f of t is the probability of death or the event occurring

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: at time step t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And although in this slide, I'm showing it

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: as an unconditional model, in general,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: you should think about this as a conditional density.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So you might be conditioning on some covariance or features

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that you have for that patient at baseline.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And very important for survival modeling

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and for the next things I'll tell you

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: are the survival function, denoted as capital S of t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And that's simply 1 minus the cumulative density function.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So it's the probability that the event occurrence, which

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is denoted here as capital T, occurs greater

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: than some little t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So it's this function, which is simply

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: given to you by the integral from 0

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: to infinity of the density.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So in pictures, this is the density.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: On the x-axis is time.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: The y-axis is the density function.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And this black curve is what I'm denoting as f of t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And this white area is capital S of t, the survival probability

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: or survival function.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Yes?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: AUDIENCE 2 All right, so I just want to be clear.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So if you were to integrate the entire curve,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: it would come out as 1, right?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Because by infinity, you're going to be n.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: PROFESSOR 1 In the way that I described it to you here,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: yes, because we're talking about the time to event.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: But often, we might be in scenarios

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: where the event may never occur.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And so you can formalize that in a couple of different ways.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: You could put it at a point mass at S of infinity.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Or you could simply say that the integral from 0 to infinity

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is some quantity less than 1.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And in the readings that I'm referencing at the very bottom

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: of the slides, it shows you how you can very easily modify

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: all of the frameworks I'm talking about here

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: to deal with that scenario where the event may never occur.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: But for the purposes of my presentation,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: you can assume that the event will always occur at some point.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: It's a very minor modification where, in essence,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: divide the densities by a constant, which

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: accounts for the fact that it wouldn't

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: integrate to 1 otherwise.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Now, a key question that has to be

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: solved when trying to use a parametric approach

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: to survival modeling is, what should that f of t look like?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: What should that density function look like?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And what I'm showing you here is a table

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: of some very commonly used density functions.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And what you see in these two columns,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: the right-hand column is the density function f of t itself.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Lambda denotes some parameter of the model.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: t is the time.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And on this second middle column is the survival function.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So this is obtained for these particular parametric forms

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: by an analytical solution.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: In essence, solving that integral from t to infinity,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: this is the analytic solution for that.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So these go by common names of exponential, Weibull,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: log-normal, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And critically, all of these have support only

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: on the positive real numbers, because the events can never

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: occur at negative time.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Now, we live in a day and age where we no longer

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: have to make standard parametric assumptions for densities.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: We could, for example, try to formalize the density

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: as some output of some deep neural network.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: But if we don't use a parametric approach,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: so there are two ways to try to do that.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: One way to do that would be to say

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that we're going to model the distribution f of t

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: as one of these things, where lambda,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: or whatever the parameters of the distribution,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: are given to you by the output of, let's say,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: a deep neural network on the covariate x.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So that would be one approach.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: A very different approach would be a nonparametric distribution,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: where you say, OK, I'm going to define f of t extremely

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: flexibly, not as one of these forms.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And there, one runs into a slightly different challenge.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Because as I'll show you in the next slide,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: to do maximum likelihood estimation

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: of these distributions from sensor data,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: one needs to make use of this survival function, s of t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And so if your f of t is complex,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and you don't have a nice analytic solution for s of t,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: then you're going to have to somehow use

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: a numerical approximation of s of t during learning.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So it's definitely possible, but it's

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: going to be a little bit more effort.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So now here's where I'm going to get into maximum likelihood

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: estimation of these distributions.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And to define for you the likelihood function,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: I'm going to break it down into two different settings.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: The first setting is an observation

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: which is uncensored, meaning we do

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: observe when the event, death, for example, occurs.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And in that case, the probability of the event,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: it's very simple.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: It's just probability of the event occurring at capital T,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: random variable t equals little t is just f of t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Done.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: However, what happens if for this data point,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: you don't observe when the event occurred because of censoring?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Well, of course, you could just throw away that data point,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: not use it in your estimation.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: But that's precisely what we mentioned

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: at the very beginning of last week's lecture

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: was the goal of survival modeling

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: to not do that because we did that to introduce bias

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: into our estimation procedure.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So we would like to be able to use that observation

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that this data point was censored.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: But the only information we can get from that observation

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is that capital T, the event time,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: must have occurred some time larger

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: than the time of censoring, which is little t here.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So we don't know precisely when capital T was,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: but we know it's something larger

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: than the observed censoring time, little t.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And that, remember, is precisely what the survival function

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is capturing.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So for a censored observation, we're

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: going to use capital S of t within the likelihood.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So now we can then combine these two

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: for censored and uncensored data.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And what we get is the following likelihood objective.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: I'm showing you here the log likelihood objective.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Recall from last week that little b of i

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: simply denotes is this observation censored or not.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So if bi is 1, it means the time that you're given

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is the time of the censoring event.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And if bi is 0, it means the time you're given

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: is the time that the event occurs.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So here, what we're going to do is now

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: sum over all of the data points in your data set

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: from little i equals 1 to little n of bi times

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: log of the probability under the censored model

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: plus 1 minus bi times log of probability

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: under the uncensored model.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And so this bi is just going to switch on which of these two

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: you're going to use for that given data point.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So the learning objective for maximum likelihood estimation

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: here is very similar to what you're

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: used to in learning distributions,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: with the big difference that for censored data,

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: we're going to use the survival function

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: to estimate its probability.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Are there any questions?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: And this, of course, could then be optimized

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: via your favorite algorithm, whether it

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: be stochastic gradient descent or second-order method

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: Yep?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: AUDIENCE 2 A question about the kind of side question.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: You mentioned that we could use equal network

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: and then combine it with the parametric function.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So is it true that we did this?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: We still have a parametric assumption

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: that we kind of mapped the input to the parameters?

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: PROFESSOR 1 Exactly.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: That's exactly right.

chunks.title: Lecture 6 Physiological Time-Series
chunks.text: So.

text: All right. So I'll begin today's lecture by giving a brief recap of risk stratification. We didn't get to finish talking about survival modeling on Thursday, and so I'll go a little bit more into that. And I'll answer some of the questions that arose during our discussions and on Piazza since. And then the vast majority of today's lecture will be talking about a new topic, in particular, physiological time series modeling. I'll give two examples of physiological time series modeling, the first one coming from monitoring patients in intensive care units, and the second one asking a very different type of question, that of diagnosing patient's heart conditions using EKGs. And both of these correspond to readings that you had for today's lecture, and we'll go into much more depth of those papers today, and I'll provide much more color around them. So just to briefly remind you where we were on Thursday, we talked about how one could form-wise risk stratification instead of as a classification problem of what would happen, let's say, in some predefined time period, rather thinking about risk stratification as a regression question or regression task. Given what you know about a patient at time 0, predicting time to event. So for example, here, the events might be death, divorce, college graduation. At patient 1, that event happened at time step 9. Patient 2, that event happened at time step 12. And for patient 4, we don't know when that event happened because it was censored. In particular, after time step 7, we no longer get a view of any of the patient's data, and so we don't know when that red dot would be, sometime in the future or never. So this is what we mean by right-censored data, which is precisely what survival modeling is aiming to solve. Are there questions about this setup first? AUDIENCE MEMBER 2 You flipped the X and the O. Yeah, I realized that. I flipped the X and the O in today's presentation, but that's not relevant. So f of t is the probability of death or the event occurring at time step t. And although in this slide, I'm showing it as an unconditional model, in general, you should think about this as a conditional density. So you might be conditioning on some covariance or features that you have for that patient at baseline. And very important for survival modeling and for the next things I'll tell you are the survival function, denoted as capital S of t. And that's simply 1 minus the cumulative density function. So it's the probability that the event occurrence, which is denoted here as capital T, occurs greater than some little t. So it's this function, which is simply given to you by the integral from 0 to infinity of the density. So in pictures, this is the density. On the x-axis is time. The y-axis is the density function. And this black curve is what I'm denoting as f of t. And this white area is capital S of t, the survival probability or survival function. Yes? AUDIENCE 2 All right, so I just want to be clear. So if you were to integrate the entire curve, it would come out as 1, right? Because by infinity, you're going to be n. PROFESSOR 1 In the way that I described it to you here, yes, because we're talking about the time to event. But often, we might be in scenarios where the event may never occur. And so you can formalize that in a couple of different ways. You could put it at a point mass at S of infinity. Or you could simply say that the integral from 0 to infinity is some quantity less than 1. And in the readings that I'm referencing at the very bottom of the slides, it shows you how you can very easily modify all of the frameworks I'm talking about here to deal with that scenario where the event may never occur. But for the purposes of my presentation, you can assume that the event will always occur at some point. It's a very minor modification where, in essence, divide the densities by a constant, which accounts for the fact that it wouldn't integrate to 1 otherwise. Now, a key question that has to be solved when trying to use a parametric approach to survival modeling is, what should that f of t look like? What should that density function look like? And what I'm showing you here is a table of some very commonly used density functions. And what you see in these two columns, the right-hand column is the density function f of t itself. Lambda denotes some parameter of the model. t is the time. And on this second middle column is the survival function. So this is obtained for these particular parametric forms by an analytical solution. In essence, solving that integral from t to infinity, this is the analytic solution for that. So these go by common names of exponential, Weibull, log-normal, and so on. And critically, all of these have support only on the positive real numbers, because the events can never occur at negative time. Now, we live in a day and age where we no longer have to make standard parametric assumptions for densities. We could, for example, try to formalize the density as some output of some deep neural network. But if we don't use a parametric approach, so there are two ways to try to do that. One way to do that would be to say that we're going to model the distribution f of t as one of these things, where lambda, or whatever the parameters of the distribution, are given to you by the output of, let's say, a deep neural network on the covariate x. So that would be one approach. A very different approach would be a nonparametric distribution, where you say, OK, I'm going to define f of t extremely flexibly, not as one of these forms. And there, one runs into a slightly different challenge. Because as I'll show you in the next slide, to do maximum likelihood estimation of these distributions from sensor data, one needs to make use of this survival function, s of t. And so if your f of t is complex, and you don't have a nice analytic solution for s of t, then you're going to have to somehow use a numerical approximation of s of t during learning. So it's definitely possible, but it's going to be a little bit more effort. So now here's where I'm going to get into maximum likelihood estimation of these distributions. And to define for you the likelihood function, I'm going to break it down into two different settings. The first setting is an observation which is uncensored, meaning we do observe when the event, death, for example, occurs. And in that case, the probability of the event, it's very simple. It's just probability of the event occurring at capital T, random variable t equals little t is just f of t. Done. However, what happens if for this data point, you don't observe when the event occurred because of censoring? Well, of course, you could just throw away that data point, not use it in your estimation. But that's precisely what we mentioned at the very beginning of last week's lecture was the goal of survival modeling to not do that because we did that to introduce bias into our estimation procedure. So we would like to be able to use that observation that this data point was censored. But the only information we can get from that observation is that capital T, the event time, must have occurred some time larger than the time of censoring, which is little t here. So we don't know precisely when capital T was, but we know it's something larger than the observed censoring time, little t. And that, remember, is precisely what the survival function is capturing. So for a censored observation, we're going to use capital S of t within the likelihood. So now we can then combine these two for censored and uncensored data. And what we get is the following likelihood objective. I'm showing you here the log likelihood objective. Recall from last week that little b of i simply denotes is this observation censored or not.
